questions.text:
A 53 year old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain. For the past three months, he has had abdominal burning and mid-epigastric pain that is worse after meals. Initially, he found relief with over-the-counter antacids, but now these medications are less effective. He has had 25-pounds unintentional weight loss in the past six months, as well as fatigue. The patient does not drink alcohol but has a 15 pack-year history of smoking and is currently smoking 0.5 packs per day. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Physical exam, including the abdominal and lymph node exams, is unremarkable. Bloodwork is obtained, and is shown below. An H. pylori test is sent, with results pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory Test
Result

questions.solution:
Dyspepsia is typically associated with benign acid reflux, although it can be a sign of more concerning conditions such as gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD), esophagitis, myocardial infarction, hiatal hernia, and cancer. The history and physical exam are important elements to help determine the underlying etiology. This patient presents with burning abdominal pain refractory to antacids in the setting of significant unintentional weight loss and iron deficiency anemia. Unintentional weight loss and iron deficiency anemia are alarm features in patients presenting with dyspepsia, and should prompt further investigation with a gastroenterology consult for upper endoscopy with biopsies given the concern for gastric cancer.

Gastric cancer is a malignant tumor of the stomach and the fifth most frequently diagnosed cancer worldwide. History should be focused on qualifying the dyspepsia and identifying risk factors associated with gastric cancer. These include a history of H. pylori and Epstein-Barr virus infections, pernicious anemia, chronic gastritis, smoking, diet of smoked or pickled foods, high-salt diet, or a family history of gastric cancer. Ethnicity might also be a risk factor, especially if patients are of Eastern Asian, Eastern European, and South American descent. The physical exam is usually unremarkable; however, it is important to do a thorough examination of the lymph node basins to evaluate for metastatic disease. Lab work often shows new onset anemia.

Upper endoscopy with biopsies of esophageal, gastric, or duodenal lesions can provide a tissue diagnosis. Any suspicious gastric ulcer should be biopsied multiple times for higher diagnostic accuracy (one (70%) versus seven (98%) sensitivity). Endoscopic ultrasound can also be performed at this time to evaluate the depth of invasion which is important for TNM staging.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Barium esophagram:
Incorrect: A barium esophagram is usually performed to assess frequent heartburn, gastric reflux, aspiration, and difficulty eating, drinking, or swallowing. This patient’s weight loss and microcytic anemia are alarm features that are concerning for gastric cancer, and while an esophagram can diagnose an intraluminal obstruction secondary to cancer, it is not the first choice for diagnosis and does not provide biopsy for tissue diagnosis.  
❌ Esophageal pH testing:
Incorrect: An esophageal pH test measures how often stomach acid enters the esophagus and how long it remains there. It is often used to diagnose acid reflux or to evaluate gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) refractory to first line antacid therapy. This patient’s weight loss and microcytic anemia are alarm features that are concerning for gastric cancer, and therefore an endoscopy with biopsies is required for diagnosis.  
✅ Upper endoscopy with biopsies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pantoprazole:
Incorrect: Antisecretory therapy with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) can relieve dyspepsia symptoms. However, in patients with alarm symptoms for gastric cancer, such as weight loss and iron deficiency anemia, further evaluation is required prior to treatment.  
❌ Ranitidine:
Incorrect: H2 blockers like ranitidine are comparable to proton pump inhibitors (PPI) for relieving symptoms of dyspepsia. In patients over 65, they are preferred to PPI due to their decreased risk of Clostridium difficile infection. However, given this patient’s alarm features for gastric cancer, additional workup is required prior to treatment.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to the office to discuss treatment options after a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer. Upper endoscopy revealed mass in the gastric fundus consistent with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Endoscopic ultrasound showed that the mass extended into the subserosal connective tissue. In addition, there were four suspicious perigastric lymph nodes, one of which contained FNA confirmed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. CT chest, abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast did not show any evidence of metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy with cytoreductive surgery
Gastrectomy with D2 lymph node dissection followed by surveillance

questions.solution:
This patient has T3N2M0 disease which is clinical Stage III. For patients with Stage III disease who are otherwise medically fit and have resectable tumors, the most appropriate next step is a diagnostic laparoscopy with cytology. A pretreatment diagnostic laparoscopy can be used to detect occult metastases. Metastatic disease (M1) can be detected via diagnostic laparoscopy in up to 30% of patients in whom metastatic disease was missed on CT. In addition, cytology testing of peritoneal fluid can help improve laparoscopic staging through identification of occult carcinomatosis.

If diagnostic laparoscopy does not find any evidence of metastatic disease, patients are referred to a medical oncologist for perioperative chemotherapy. First line chemotherapy is generally a two-agent cytotoxic regimen consisting of a fluoropyrimidine and platinum alkylating agent (i.e., fluorouracil and oxaliplatin).  After perioperative chemotherapy is completed, the patient is then re-staged via CT imaging. If they have resectable disease, surgery is recommended.

The standard of care for surgical management of gastric cancer is a gastrectomy with D2 lymphadenectomy. If an R0, or margin negative, resection is achieved, patients can either be followed by surveillance or receive additional adjuvant chemotherapy. Given this patient’s node positive status, they would likely be referred for additional chemotherapy post-operatively.  

Option Analysis

❌ Endoscopic resection:
Incorrect: Endoscopic resection is an excellent option for patients without lymph node involvement who meet the standard criteria: mucosal tumor without ulceration, size ≤20 mm in diameter, differentiated histology, and without known lymphovascular invasion. Given this patient’s lymph node involvement, endoscopic resection is not an appropriate option. This patient with cT3 cancer requires additional workup with diagnostic laparoscopy with cytology.  
❌ Hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy with cytoreductive surgery:
Incorrect: Hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) or laparoscopic HIPEC may be a therapeutic alternative for carefully selected stage IV patients in the setting of ongoing clinical trials and is under further clinical investigation. Given this patient’s lack of metastatic disease, the patient is considered  stage III, not stage IV, and this is not an appropriate option. This patient with cT3 cancer requires additional workup with diagnostic laparoscopy with cytology.  
✅ Diagnostic laparoscopy with cytology:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gastrectomy with D2 lymph node dissection followed by surveillance:
Incorrect: Prior to any surgery, this patient will require further evaluation of metastatic disease and subsequent perioperative chemotherapy. Patients with cT1 cancer are potentially upfront surgical candidates, but this patient with cT3 cancer requires additional workup with diagnostic laparoscopy with cytology  
❌ Palliative care consult:
Incorrect: Patients with locally advanced unresectable or metastatic disease are usually referred for palliative care. While involving palliative care is an excellent option for all patients to help manage the social, financial, and emotional aspects of cancer care, it is not the next step for this patient with Stage III cancer who needs additional workup with diagnostic laparoscopy with cytology.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease presents with dysphagia and unintentional weight loss over the past three months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with lisinopril. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 76/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination is notable for mild epigastric tenderness without palpable neck lymphadenopathy. CBC shows mild microcytic anemia and LFTs are within normal limits. An upper endoscopy reveals a 2.5 cm lesion in the lower esophagus, and biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma with evidence of submucosal invasion. CT and PET scans show no evidence of metastasis. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) followed by radiation therapy

questions.solution:
This patient with a 2.5 cm lesion in the lower esophagus without lymphadenopathy or evidence of metastasis and biopsy showing submucosal invasion has stage 1A or 2 esophageal cancer. He should have a surgical consultation for esophagectomy with intent to cure.  

For very early-stage cancer stage 1A, where the tumor is less than 2 cm and is confined to the superficial esophageal layers, endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) is often sufficient with the intent to cure. In early-stage cancers more than 2 cm in size without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis and without high-risk features as seen in this patient, surgical resection with esophagectomy is generally the preferred treatment, aiming for complete removal of cancerous tissue and cure with adjuvant chemoradiation and surveillance.    

When esophageal cancer is locally advanced (stages II and III), a combination of neoadjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy is typically employed before considering surgery. This approach can reduce tumor size, making surgical resection more feasible and potentially improving outcomes. In cases where surgery is not an option due to extensive disease spread or patient comorbidities, chemoradiation therapy serves as the primary treatment. Throughout the treatment process, supportive care to address symptoms, nutritional needs, and overall quality of life is crucial.  

Option Analysis

✅ Esophagectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR):
Incorrect: EMR is typically reserved for very early stage 1A esophageal cancer that is limited to the superficial layers of the esophagus and less than 2 cm in size. Given the size of the lesion (2.5 cm) and submucosal involvement, EMR alone is not appropriate.
❌ Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by esophagectomy:
Incorrect: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is generally considered for locally advanced esophageal cancers. In this patient with early-stage disease, immediate surgery is more appropriate, as the tumor is limited and there is no evidence of metastasis or deep invasion requiring preoperative chemotherapy.     
❌ Radiation therapy only:
Incorrect: Exclusive use of radiation therapy is not the standard of care for early-stage esophageal cancer without evidence of metastasis. Esophagectomy can potentially be curative.
❌ Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) followed by radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Combining EMR with radiation therapy is not a standard approach to treating esophageal cancer. This patient’s lesion, given its characteristics and stage, warrants consideration for surgical resection as the primary treatment modality aiming for a potential curate.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman was referred to the hepatology clinic due to the finding of a new liver nodule on surveillance ultrasound. The patient has a history of cirrhosis due to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis and the ultrasound of the liver showed an 8 mm liver nodule. A small amount of ascites was also seen on the abdominal ultrasound. Current medications include atorvastatin and lactulose. The patient has no new symptoms. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. The abdomen is soft and mildly distended without a small fluid wave. Serum laboratory studies reveal normal transaminases and normal alpha-fetoprotein. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Liver ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein in 3-6 months
Triple phase liver protocol Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the abdomen
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen

questions.solution:
This 52-year-old woman with cirrhosis was referred to the hepatology clinic due to a new 8 mm liver nodule that was seen on surveillance ultrasound. Given this patient’s history of cirrhosis, there should be a high index of suspicion for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The nodule is found to be less than 1 cm, the patient is asymptomatic, and laboratory studies are within normal limits, therefore obtaining a liver ultrasound and repeat alpha-fetoprotein level in 3-6 months is the most appropriate next step in management.

Patients with cirrhosis are at elevated risk for HCC. Patients with HCC can remain asymptomatic for a long time, and therefore may present late in the disease course. Routine screening for HCC with surveillance ultrasound is recommended every 6 months to detect early lesions. Further testing and surveillance is based on the size of liver nodules found as well as results of laboratory studies (serum transaminases and alpha-fetoprotein).

In patients with cirrhosis and no liver nodules, and normal laboratory studies, routine surveillance can occur every six months. In patients with cirrhosis and a liver nodule less than 1 cm and normal laboratory studies, the nodule should be considered high-risk nodule and liver ultrasound, and serum alpha-fetoproteinshould be repeated every three to six months. In patients with a liver nodule larger than 1 cm or elevated AFP, further imaging with computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is necessary to determine the best next step in management.
   

Figure 1. Liver nodule representing hepatocellular carcinoma on CT scan 

Option Analysis

✅ Liver ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein in 3-6 months:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Liver ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein in one year:
Incorrect: Surveillance for patients with cirrhosis is typically ultrasound with or without alpha fetal protein testing every 6 months. In patients like this one with a liver nodule less than 1cm and normal alpha fetoprotein level, the nodule should be considered elevated risk, and the patient should have repeat ultrasound and bloodwork between 3 and 6 months. 
❌ Triple phase liver protocol Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the abdomen:
Incorrect: In patients with abnormal LFTs, elevated AFP and a liver nodule equal to or greater than 1cm, a malignant liver nodule should be suspected, and CT or MRI should be performed to categorize the lesion using LI-RADS to determine the likely diagnosis and appropriate treatment. In patients like this one who are asymptomatic with a liver nodule less than 1cm and normal alpha fetoprotein, the nodule should be considered elevated risk, and the patient should have repeat ultrasound and lab work between 3 and 6 months. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen:
Incorrect: In patients with abnormal LFTs, elevated AFP and a liver nodule equal to or greater than 1cm, a malignant liver nodule should be suspected, and CT or MRI should be performed and LI-RADS should be used to determine the likely diagnosis and appropriate treatment. In patients like this one with a liver nodule less than 1cm and a normal alpha-fetoprotein level, the nodule should be considered elevated risk, and the patient should have repeat ultrasound and lab work between 3 and 6 months. 
❌ Alpha-fetoprotein in 3-6 months:
Incorrect: Alpha-fetoprotein level alone in 3-6 months would be an inadequate follow-up. This patient should have abdominal ultrasound and alpha fetal protein testing in 3-6 months to follow the high-risk lesion.
